title: Hormonal fluctuations across the menstrual cycle and their impact on speech: A data mining, modelling and resource generation project
abstractText:
Differences in verbal skills between men and women are well documented, indicating that reproductive hormones play a role in speech and language function. Our laboratory conducted studies looking at how speaking and listening to speech are affected as women pass from low to high hormone phases of the 28 day menstrual cycle. By measuring fine-grained aspects of spoken syllables and words, menstrual cycle effects on speech rate and accuracy were discovered.

The new project will investigate women's speech in more detail by combining data from previous studies into one large database. In-depth analysis of speech recordings from women studied at key points across the menstrual cycle will be conducted. Data will be further investigated with statistical modelling to shed light on the underlying organisation of speech changes across the menstrual cycle. This will improve understanding of how hormonal fluctuations affect communication in young women.

Findings will lay the groundwork for future research to examine how hormonal changes at menopause impact speech. Women are over-represented in sectors of the workforce where effective speech and language are paramount. This project will provide the foundation for applied research into how communication is affected by ovarian hormones across the female life span.
impactText: The project created a unique database of speech and related behaviour derived from the study of healthy adult men and women aged 20-30 years. Specifically, women were studied at two or three points across the menstrual cycle and men were studied once. Speech measures included novel tasks and professional quality data recordings designed to enable both microacoustic and macrobehavioural analysis of speech. The main theoretical contribution has been to establish that women operate at different functional states which are hormonally related, and that these affect the micro- and macro-behavioural features of communication-based behaviour and cognition. Since completion of the ESRC project, we have collected new data for a study of women in their 40's and 50's which is designed to investigate the speech and related behavioural measures studied in our original database in relation to mid-life hormone changes and menopause. This work would not have been possible without the knowledge and experience gained through the ESRC-funded research. The volunteers from the menopause study frequently express concerns that women's experiences of hormone-related effects on behaviour and cognition are not fully recognised by society. Thus, a future objective is to learn more about women's perceived information gaps regarding hormone effects on communication and cognition. This information would inform the direction of our research and enhance its future impact. Other economic and societal impact has been delivered mainly in the form of education to the clinical practitioners and university students who have read our publications, been to the conference presentations or attended university seminars from our research group. findingsText: This project was based on a growing field of research which supports the role of reproductive hormones in shaping human brain and behaviour. An important set of behaviours affected by hormones in many species are those related to communication. Our main focus was to study the impact of female reproductive hormones on human speech. We studied healthy women at various points in the menstrual cycle that coincided with particular hormone level combinations. Prior studies from our laboratory reported that high levels of hormones were associated with patterns of speech production (saying words or syllables) which we were able to measure with very fine-grained analysis of the speech waveform. We also found differences in the perception of speech (detecting syllables) and in complex verbal tasks (creating word lists). More recently we started to take direct measures of hormone levels by analysing blood samples from our study volunteers. This has allowed us to examine more precise links between ovarian hormones and speech. The ESRC grant supported a year of detailed analysis of thousands of speech samples and the compilation of an extensive database of hormones, speech and related behaviour. The database contains information about 25 women studied across two phases of the menstrual cycle, 30 women studied across three phases of the menstrual cycle, and 20 men. It is a unique resource that our research group will continue to analyse for a more in-depth understanding about the role that hormones play in modulating complex communication functions in healthy women. These findings add to growing scientific literatures in the psychology and cognitive neuroscience of sex differences and hormone effects on behaviour and cognition. Our findings specifically inform the body of research investigating menstrual cycle effects on behavioural measures of speech perception and speech production. We built an extensive database which will serve our laboratory for many years in the development of coherent models of how reproductive hormones modulate speech functions in healthy women. Specific discoveries, such as the stratification of effects in women experiencing regular or atypical menstrual cycles, have broader biomedical relevance. New work is examining applications of the menstrual cycle based model on young women to the study of menopause in healthy women at mid-life. Efforts to inform the wider public about the effects of hormones on women's communication, as well as the factors that contribute to individual differences, will follow each stage of scientific development and reporting.
